text: the toilet might be a nice place to sit
down and read the Sunday paper but if
you're using it for its intended use
well you're doing it wrong turns out the
sitting toilet didn't really come into
widespread use until the mid 19th
century and books from as far back as
the 1960s suggest its adoption in the
Western world may not be as good for our
bodies as we think sitting many
proponents of squatting say is not the
natural position your body should be in
for this task when you sit they say your
anal canal winds up being at an angle
from your rectum and the pubic callous
muscle aka your pelvic floor chokes the
rectum meaning your body is making it
harder for it to do what you want it to
do
this results in straining during bowel
movement which increases the pressure in
your abdomen
some research says this added pressure
and straining may contribute to
gastrointestinal issues like hemorrhoids
before the toilet we all just squatted
in the woods
more over pots and pits in the ground in
fact sitting on something resembling a
toilet was reserved only for royalty
studies now suggest that we should all
still be squatting when you squat the
muscles in your pelvic floor relaxed
allowing the rectum to be straight
I'm giving waste and easy path to exit
the body a small 2003 study found that
people who tried squatting took 51
seconds to move their bowels while the
same people took an average of 130
seconds when they set most of the
subjects also said the task was easier
when they moved from a sit to a squat
there's no need to tear your bathroom
apart and install a hole to squat over
there are various devices and
accessories available one is called the
squatty potty to help you achieve what
nature may have intended on a normal
toilet you can still sit on the toilet
to read the paper but maybe that's all
you should be doing
you
